As a teacher, I hate giving bad grades — even to those who deserve it! But I do it! I take it as a personal failing when I cannot reach out to and motivate a failing student. (I’ve passed students I caught cheating after they agreed to twice as much extra work.) I feel badly, but sometimes it’s a wake-up call to the student who thinks he is entitled to a good grade simply because his parents pay tuition.
Some do. If they are unprofessional, immature, and venal. Most will bend over backward to be fair to a student they don’t like.

Sometimes; but, it will get him/her in a lot of trouble if you can prove it, at least here in the U.S. An example would be if your essay is fully correct/factual—something another teacher and/or the principal would agree with you on—but the teacher in question gives you a lower grade, just because. That’s discrimination and/or harassment.

May be yes sometimes...because once I have heard about my friend during my student life..He once raised his voice near the teacher and then he never passed out his degree. It shouldnot be done according to me, because student life is full of pressure like from friends, society, family all that and a teacher thinking height is not the same as the student. Revenge or giving less mark is not the way unless you can make him/her good through your trick. According to me todays students are very updated,unless you can make them interested in your topic, they will not get any interest in you.Mainly, I donot give marks according to likings..but I make them fear of giving less marks in annual exam if they cannot pass in all the test of my subject.

My English teacher once said I handed an assignment in late despite her collecting it with the rest of the class. It brought my average down to the low 90’s. This was earlier in the year and since have improved my relationship with my teacher, but I still had horrible anxiety over it. I talked to my parents, friends, sister and therapist about it, and they all encouraged me to talk to her for a second time but I was worried she would yell at me again, so I just did nothing.
It usually happens that teachers mostly focus on that students who stay respectly with them but sometimes such students are not deserving for such better grades…

This kind of thing happens even in the most developed of educational systems. It just doesn’t come out because nobody finds or looks for it. When I was in tenth grade there was one test I was confident about above all other tests, it was for my math class and I was sure I was gonna get a good grade but to my surprise I got a 60 while the laziest kid in class got a 105 and he was a average in math while I was alternating between a B and A. I was shocked by that and very upset over it but eventually I came to realize that grade because apparently I was ahead of myself in math class and was even tutoring my classmates and she didn’t want that to get in my head. Further proof is the fact the teacher never handed back the test and only showed us our grades in her gradebook.
Some less reputable teachers might. I, personally, never have. Good, fair teachers don't “give” grades; students earn them with the quality of work they do. Like them or not, I'm just the bookkeeper.

Yes, more often than not. Two main reasons: the first is that they are (usually) older. The second is that people everywhere hate and cannot tolerate their enemies prospering. Remember, ALL humans have an ego.

In my opinion, they won’t. The job of teacher is very great and lofty because teachers devote their whole life to the educational enterprise. A standard to judge you are a good teacher is that you can treat all the students equally. Teachers are very patient with all the students. And the duty of teacher is to educate the students to become what they want to be. The grade of the student is based on his paper results rather than teacher’s own thoughts.

Not saying it never happens, but if so, rarely. Grades are not ‘given’, grades are earned. If a student asked me why I ‘gave them’ such and such a grade (and a few have), my response, “you don’t see a Santa suit on me, I don’t give grades, I record your progress in class (through various means) and that alone determines your grade.”
I am a teacher and I do not do that. I judge their work for what it is. They put in the work they get a good grade if they don’t then they won’t simple as that. The students earn their grades.
They have to follow some guidelines. If they're essays I think they're apt to grade you harsher. They'll probably note you “don't follow directions”
Quite possible. Depends on the teacher Though. Some teachers even give bad grade when in a bad mood.
Generally not. But there are exceptions. If teachers distribute success criteria (a rubric) then it’s very easy to justify the marks that are assigned to a piece of work.
I cannot speak for others but I NEVER let my personal feelings toward a student affect the grade they earned.
Sadly, yes it does happen. I never did it to my students, but I have heard of it happening.
Yes
Yes
No
